A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Does the concept of a/an Integral Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an Integral Domain is defined as a commutative ring that is nonzero and does not have nontrivial zero divisors. This concept is foundational in abstract algebra, particularly in the study of rings and fields. However, the definition of the Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension specifically pertains to field theory, focusing on the automorphisms of a field extension that fix the base field. Fields are a special kind of integral domain, specifically, they are integral domains in which every nonzero element has a multiplicative inverse.\n\nIn the context of defining and understanding the Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension, the field itself inherently satisfies the properties of an integral domain because all fields are integral domains. However, the specific concept of an integral domain does not need to be explicitly defined or invoked to define or understand the Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension. The definition of a field (and thus the properties of an integral domain) is implicitly understood and sufficient for the purposes of discussing field extensions and their automorphisms. Therefore, while integral domains are related to fields, the specific concept of an integral domain is not necessary to make sense of the Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension.
